items.title: Syrian Refugees Strain Resources in Jordan
items.abstract: Despite plans by aid organizations to help at least 50,000 urban refugees, a large number will be left out because of the rising numbers of Syrians fleeing across the border each day.
keywords: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

items.title: Thursday Reading: Home Composting in the City
items.abstract: Home composting in the city, piecing together the fiscal deal’s effect on taxpayers, talking to other parents about guns and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: ‘Mexsicko City’ Turns a Corner in Its Clean Air Marathon
items.abstract: Even amid other environmental gains, it is the improvement in air quality that has most burnished the city’s green credentials.

items.title: Major Cities Grind to a Halt and Face Days of Digging Out Snow
items.abstract: In New York, the National Weather Service said 26.8 inches of snow had fallen on Central Park by midnight, making this the city’s second-biggest snowstorm since 1869.

items.title: Donald Trump Finds New City to Insult: Brussels
items.abstract: “It’s like living in a hellhole right now,” Donald J. Trump told the Fox Business Network anchor Maria Bartiromo.

items.title: New York City Officials Announce Efforts to Fight Zika Virus
items.abstract: With seven confirmed cases in the state, including three in the city, health administrators announced plans to prevent the virus from spreading.

items.title: Howard Koslow Dies at 91; Artist Designed Stamps for 40 Years
items.abstract: Mr. Koslow was a painter and illustrator who for more than four decades designed many of the most recognizable stamps issued by the United States Postal Service.

items.title: Vancouver Explores Its First Nations Roots
items.abstract: Beyond the totem poles long displayed in Stanley Park, visitors to Vancouver can now gain a fuller appreciation for the area’s native people.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: Washington’s Strong Economy, Financed by Taxpayers, Takes Hit From Shutdown
items.abstract: As the country nears the end of its third week of a government shutdown, the nation’s capital has borne the brunt of its consequences.

items.title: Relief for New York City’s Transit Deserts? Commuter Trains Might Help
items.abstract: A planned billion-dollar rail expansion in the Bronx is fueling a larger debate over using aboveground trains to supplement subway and bus service.

items.title: In Texas, Trump’s Visit Offers Two Views of a Border
items.abstract: President Trump used McAllen, Tex., as the backdrop for his border visit Thursday. It is a city of 142,000, a place of synagogues, country clubs and misperceptions.

items.title: Students in Rural America Ask, ‘What Is a University Without a History Major?’
items.abstract: Financial and enrollment woes at schools like the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point have led to a scramble for fixes, such as dropping longstanding liberal arts degrees.

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: City Schools Are ‘Staying Open,’ Mayor Eric Adams Says
items.abstract: But the spike in Omicron cases has created trepidation for many parents.

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?

items.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
items.abstract: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.

items.title: How Remote Work Is Devastating New York City’s Commuter Rails
items.abstract: Before the pandemic, they relied on office workers, who spent up to $500 a month on tickets. At the M.T.A., those sales are down 75 percent.
